A one-word reference to "India" does not justify the headline

"Many analysts have been arguing that the best way for policy makers to respond to slowing growth is further liberalization of India’s economy, large parts of which are still heavily regulated. The government could, for instance, make it easier for foreigners to invest in industries like retail, aviation and insurance that need more capital. "

This quote from the accompanying article is indicative of the one-sided reporting about India's economy in the mainstream media, both within and outside the country. While the going was "good," they attributed it all to liberalization and deregulation; little mention was made of growing inequality and the huge environmental and social impacts of new growth. Now that growth has stalled, the remedy is unchanged: less government, more private sector, more foreign investment. The majority of Indians are still waiting for the trickle-down effect.

A useful result, if it tamps down some of the exaggerated reaction to the thrashing of mighty Scotland. I agree with a number of the US players who, while acknowledging their mistakes and-sorry-inferiority as a team, felt the scoreline was flattering to Brazil. Also useful if it serves as a serious wakeup call with regard to our aging back line. Maybe Onyewu won't actually make it back from his knee injury. But seriously, it's not like he was all that great before the injury. Cherundolo is still the USA's most consistent player. Jermaine Jones, who was so effective against Scotland, showed why so many observers remain unconvinced. What was the point of that violent challenge on Neymar, on the sideline at the halfway line? By then the  ref had already made it clear he wasn't going to be cutting anyone any slack. This was just stupidity on Jones' part. But even more stupid was Klinsmann's comment about the USA needing "to hurt people". In that context, maybe Jones was just doing what he had been told to do by the coach. If that's the case, Klinsmann should be warned by his employer that that is unacceptable. You can be a tough and effective defender without going out to injure your opponent. Ironic that Klinsmann, who spent a long career avoiding violent tackles as a striker is now telling his players to go out and hurt creative players. It's a shame, actually. And not something to applaud.

Nike's uniform designs have seldom been good. They do tend to be a little better whey Nike is constrained by clubs and countries with some tradition to respect. But remember the early days of MLS, when Nike did all the teams uniforms. They were almost all awful, and most of them ended up being to some degree or another, black. That, I was told, was because studies had shown that the Oakland Raiders jersey was the best-selling NFL shirt. No joke. By and large, adidas has done a much better job, for MLS and for the clubs and national teams to which it provides uniforms. Maybe it's all that soccer tradition...

Prediction:
There was a major economic tremor in roughly late August or early September in 2007. Six months later Bush signed into law a mini-stimulus of $150 billion, to avoid the massive cratering of demand all knew had to happen as a result of Bush moving $10 to $15 trillion (with a "T" from the demand side of our economy to the supply side). It was too little too late, and in September 2008 came the big one. The minimalist approach resulted in a 'stimulus' bill of nearly $800 billion, negated by $350 billion in tax cuts, and another $350 billion in reduced spending by government at the state level and minimal reforms for the banksters. The result was the problem never went away. The Global economy and global civilization nearly fell into the the abyss. Perhaps saved so by so little as the 'cash for clunkers' program. In essence, the fall into the abyss was avoided, but nothing else was fixed or solved. What comes next is a gigantic fall off the ledge that the world has been clinging to. The only question is when?

All the while, conservatives and their austerian twin will still be blaming it on the liberals. The rest of us, now a majority, will be eating dirt.
